channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Judge pauses Trump administration plans to end deportation protection for Venezuelans
item.description: A federal judge on Monday paused plans by the Trump administration to end temporary legal protections for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans, a week before they were scheduled to expire.
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge on Monday paused plans by the Trump administration to end temporary legal protections for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans, a week before they were scheduled to expire.

(Image credit: Cristian Hernandez)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Advocates say flawed 'checklist' targets Venezuelans for deportation under archaic wartime act
item.description: Flawed deportation 'checklist' targets Venezuelans using tattoos as one gang identifier. But experts say Tren de Aragua doesn't use tattoos for member identification.
item.content:encoded:
Flawed deportation 'checklist' targets Venezuelans using tattoos as one gang identifier. But experts say Tren de Aragua doesn't use tattoos for member identification.

(Image credit: El Salvador Press Presidency Office)
item.dc:creator: Sergio Martínez-Beltrán

item.title: A midwife says of the aid cuts in Afghanistan: 'No one prioritizes women's lives.'
item.description: With the abrupt shutdown of USAID funding, many clinics, including those serving women in remote areas, have shuttered. Midwives are reporting that mothers and babies are dying as a result.
item.content:encoded:
With the abrupt shutdown of USAID funding, many clinics, including those serving women in remote areas, have shuttered. Midwives are reporting that mothers and babies are dying as a result.

(Image credit: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Diaa Hadid

item.title: The woman who ran for president 50 years before she could vote
item.description: NPR animator and illustrator Jackie Lay tells the story of Victoria Woodhull, who wrote a letter to the New York Herald in 1870 announcing she was running for president — 50 years before women would be allowed to vote.
item.content:encoded: NPR animator and illustrator Jackie Lay tells the story of Victoria Woodhull, who wrote a letter to the New York Herald in 1870 announcing she was running for president — 50 years before women would be allowed to vote.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Lay

item.title: Trump Policies Lead to a Wave of Reverse Migration
item.description: During his campaign, President Trump promised to stem migration to the United States. And since taking office his administration has deported plane loads of people, some of whom were in the U.S. legally. Hundreds of deportees have been sent to prison in El Salvador. And President Trump has essentially closed the door to immigrants seeking to enter the country through the border with Mexico. These policies have provoked so-called reverse migration, where people go back to the places they once fled. And that has knock-on effects for other countries. We go to a tiny island in Panama to see the effects of U.S. immigration policy.
item.content:encoded: During his campaign, President Trump promised to stem migration to the United States. And since taking office his administration has deported plane loads of people, some of whom were in the U.S. legally. Hundreds of deportees have been sent to prison in El Salvador. And President Trump has essentially closed the door to immigrants seeking to enter the country through the border with Mexico. These policies have provoked so-called reverse migration, where people go back to the places they once fled. And that has knock-on effects for other countries. We go to a tiny island in Panama to see the effects of U.S. immigration policy.
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta

item.title: Supreme Court seems ready to let religious groups opt out of unemployment compensation laws
item.description: The case was brought by a chapter of Catholic Charities in Wisconsin, which says that it should be able to opt out of the mandatory state unemployment compensation system.
item.content:encoded:
The case was brought by a chapter of Catholic Charities in Wisconsin, which says that it should be able to opt out of the mandatory state unemployment compensation system.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: Entire staff at federal agency that funds libraries and museums put on leave
item.description: The staff of the Institute of Museum and Library Services was placed on administrative leave Monday morning, following a meeting between IMLS leadership and DOGE staff.
item.content:encoded:
The staff of the Institute of Museum and Library Services was placed on administrative leave Monday morning, following a meeting between IMLS leadership and DOGE staff.

(Image credit: Shannon Finney)
item.dc:creator: Andrew Limbong

item.title: 4 astronauts to be the first to orbit the poles on a privately funded SpaceX mission
item.description: SpaceX is planning a launch as early as Monday evening. If successful, it will mark the first crewed mission to polar orbit and the first mission to cultivate mushrooms as a crop
item.content:encoded:
SpaceX is planning a launch as early as Monday evening. If successful, it will mark the first crewed mission to polar orbit and the first mission to cultivate mushrooms as a crop

(Image credit: SpaceX)
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: White House says it's 'case closed' on the Signal group chat review
item.description: Last week, the White House said the National Security Council, the White House counsel office and President Trump adviser Elon Musk were all looking into the mishap. But now, that probe has wrapped
item.content:encoded:
Last week, the White House said the National Security Council, the White House counsel office and President Trump adviser Elon Musk were all looking into the mishap. But now, that probe has wrapped

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: Presidents can be elected twice. Trump could try end runs around that, experts say
item.description: The 22nd Amendment bans a person from being elected U.S. president more than twice. But some legal experts point to plausible strategies that President Trump could try to serve a third term.
item.content:encoded:
The 22nd Amendment bans a person from being elected U.S. president more than twice. But some legal experts point to plausible strategies that President Trump could try to serve a third term.

(Image credit: Brendan Smialowski)
item.dc:creator: Hansi Lo Wang
